description.narrative: Project Outputs 175 homes retrofitted and 100 sanitation solutions provided. 50 sets of construction tool kits distributed. 1500 individuals trained in in safer construction, home maintenance, conflict mitigation, disaster risk reduction, financial literacy and technical construction methods. 277 participants trained in technical construction best practices. 50 masons certified as specialists in DRR and technical retrofit construction methods. 123 individuals (81% female) trained in basic home maintenance. 35 DRR trainees certified through the local civic protection system and the Mayor’s office as a disaster emergency management team. Community-led projects implemented and completed through 10 community-managed contracts (2 for women contractors): Paving of the entrance to zone, Plaine du Clu-de-Sac (PCS) (171m); canal clearing and drainage repair to reduce flooding and prevent disease; identification and installation of street signage for 34 streets; paved (concrete) walkways between houses; and repaired recreation facility. The health care program in Simon Pele was successfully implemented achieving the following results: o 3,716 children and adults were immunized against various diseases. o 4,970 hygiene kits were distributed to households and eight schools. o 4,839 medical records were developed and distributed to patients in the community. o A 15 person health care committee was established to implement the project and continue to find solutions to community health and sanitation issues. o A disaster response/evaluation plan was developed and 5,409 emergency kits were distributed in the community. o In all 18,546 community members from Simon Pele participated in training and education campaigns, with a focus on hygiene and sanitation in schools/homes and health care services from mobile clinics.

This engagement was a direct continuation of the Enabling Neighborhood Revival in Haiti 1 project in Simon-Pelé. It sought to support structural and social regeneration of Simon-Pelé leveraging the experience and outcomes of the first project. Structural focus included repairing and retrofitting damaged homes, provision of sanitation, and basic infrastructure and improvements in the housing value chain and construction practices. Social regeneration consisted of enabling displaced residents to return to safe homes and strengthening community capacity to deal with neighborhood, environmental and health shocks and stresses through training and healthcare services.
